ayes: alexander, antonini, bradford bell, w. lee, olague

project_descr: Appeal of Preliminary Mitigated Negative Declaration - The proposed project would consist of construction of a residential and commercial mixed-use development after demolition of a defunct bottling plant facility at 5800 Third Street (Assessor’s Block 5431A, Lot 001), at the southwest corner of Third Street and Carroll Avenue in the Bayview neighborhood. The project would include 355 multi-family residential units in four buildings, 13,000 gross square feet (gsf) of ground floor retail space in two of the buildings that would be along Third Street, and 379 off-street parking spaces in the four buildings. The four buildings would total 641,920 gsf in size, ranging in height from 50 to 60 feet tall (four to five stories) and would be built around a central plaza and a private driveway with two visitor loading spaces, with access from Carroll Avenue. Sixteen surface parking spaces for the retail uses would be provided on the south side of the project site, with access provided from a right-turn-only driveway on Third Street at the southern boundary of the site. Twenty surface parking spaces for visitors would be provided along the central private driveway. Currently, the 5.75-acre site is occupied by a three-story, 103,000-gsf closed Coca-Cola bottling plant constructed in 1966, which would be demolished. Current use of the site is temporary parking of moving company trucks and charter buses. The site is the proposed Bayview Hunters Point Redevelopment Projects and Zoning Health Center Activity Node. The project would require Conditional Use Authorization for a Planned Unit Development and for residential uses in an M-1 District by the Planning Commission, which is a public hearing process.
action: without hearing, item continued to july 21, 2005
ayes: alexander, antonini, bradford bell, w. lee, olague

project_descr: Request for Discretionary Review of Building Permit Application No. 2003.12.21.3024 proposing to legalize a stair penthouse and elevator mechanical equipment constructed without permits at the rear of the roof of the subject building, which houses Shoe Biz,
preliminary_recommendation: do not take discretrionary review and approve the project
note: This item was originally heard on Thursday, April 21, 2005 when the Commission held a public hearing, took public testimony, closed the public hearing, and passed a motion to take discretionary review and disapprove the permit. Subsequently, a written request that the Discretionary Review case be re-heard by the Commission was accepted on the basis that new information had become available. The Commission President instructed that this item be scheduled for possible reconsideration.
speakers: david levy, paul virl, jim siegel, ali ghambarian, michael musleh, philip telesco, matthew brasler, mehran esmair, noshin ansarinia, mark brennan, matthew brennan, andrew smith, joe o'donaghue

speaker_statements.speaker: david levy
lines: thanks the commission for hearing them
requests reconsideration and a motion to deny discretionary review
states nearby structures are not visible from the project and no neighbors oppose
says his client did not intentionally try to deceive anyone

speaker_statements.speaker: paul virl
lines: was not aware of any elevator hazard
opposes taking discretionary review

speaker_statements.speaker: jim siegel
lines: says the business is an asset to the haight-ashbury district
notes his own building is covered in graffiti while the project owner actively reduces graffiti and loitering
believes the opponent is being vindictive

speaker_statements.speaker: ali ghambarian
lines: has published the magazine for about 20 years
says the project owners are respected neighborhood business owners who contribute significantly to the community
believes they would not do anything illegal

speaker_statements.speaker: michael musleh
lines: owns a business in the area
says it is difficult to survive on haight street because it is touristy and expensive
notes the sponsor is one of the oldest businesses in the area
says the sponsor has sustained his business and supported other tenants and business owners

speaker_statements.speaker: philip telesco
lines: san francisco business owner providing hardware and software to small businesses
says the sponsor is one of the hardest-working business owners he has met
calls the sponsor honest and reliable

speaker_statements.speaker: matthew brasler
lines: supports the project sponsor
says the sponsor is honest, generous, and a hard worker

speaker_statements.speaker: john curtis
lines: banker for over five years
has worked with the sponsor and says he has strong character
notes the street has been cleaner since the sponsor moved in

speaker_statements.speaker: mehran esmair
lines: says safety and food compliance required the machine room and roof access
did not intend to hide or deceive anyone
states the proposed location is the only seismically feasible one

speaker_statements.speaker: noshin ansarinia
lines: says non-developers do their best but sometimes make mistakes
says no one wants to endure what they are going through
asks to allow the mechanical room where proposed

speaker_statements.speaker: mark brennan
lines: argues the case should not be reheard because no new information was presented
warns a rehearing would open a pandora’s box
calls accusations that opponents are vindictive outrageous

speaker_statements.speaker: matthew brennan
lines: states law requires mechanical rooms to be as close to the elevator as possible
says he has not seen mechanical rooms placed on roofs
argues a rehearing should occur the same day under robert’s rules of order

speaker_statements.speaker: andrew smith
lines: does not support the project
says the sponsor intended a roof mechanical room from the start
believes the sponsor should be held accountable for any mistakes and pay for abusing the process
opposes a new hearing because there is no new information

speaker_statements.speaker: joe o’donaghue
lines: says the case should not be reheard
notes no new evidence was presented
states everyone must abide by the same laws
acknowledges the sponsor is nice but says he violated the laws twice

project_descr: Request for Discretionary Review of Building Permit Application 2004.10.06.6166, to construct a one-story vertical addition on the existing two-family building and to construct a horizontal addition to the rear of the building.

lines: he submitted a letter from the homeowners association who are not in support of the addition because it will affect the neighborhood

speaker_statements.speaker: leon taylor
lines: in order to rehabilitate the building, there is a need for reinforcement of the foundation
the addition would encourage a large family to live there
out of 22 houses located on the south side of the street, 12 are two-story over garage
all the neighbors on both sides of the structure are supporting the project

ayes: alexander, antonini, bradford bell, w. lee, olague
